titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Gustav Glück Papers LSC.1768

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2021 January 7.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2026-01-16 14:25:14 -0800.

did.unittitle: Gustav Glück papers
did.abstract: Gustav Glück (1871-1952) was an art historian from Vienna, Austria who settled in Santa Monica, California in the early 1940s. The Glück papers contain materials dated from 1898 to 1956 and include correspondence, manuscripts, and research notes.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in German, French, and English.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Gustav Glück papers (Collection 1768). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Gloria Gonzaelz under the supervision of Kelley Wolfe Bachli, 2013.

The Gustav Glück papers were gifted to to UCLA Arts Library Special Collections from the Jules Langsner Estate in 1968. During the processing of the Langsner papers, the Gustav Glück papers were removed and established as a separate collection.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Gustav Glück was born in Vienna, Austria on April 6, 1871. Glück was an Austrian art historian, author, and student of Franz Wickhoff. In 1900, Glück became an Assistant at the Vienna Kunsthistorisches Museum, and was subsequently promoted to a series of positions including Curator and de facto Director in 1911, and Director of the museum in 1916. In 1931, he resigned from his position and left Vienna for London in 1938. In 1942, Glück moved to Santa Monica, California where he died on November 18, 1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of personal and scholarly papers of Gustav Glück, a Venitian art historian. Materials are in German, French and English languages and span the first half of the 20th century. The Glück papers include correspondence and research notes, as well as typed and written manuscripts.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in the original order established by the donor.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Jules Langsner Papers (Collection Number 1748). Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
